semantic_title: Dominant and Nondominant Side Assignment for Neurological Conditions
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 6. Chapter 6: Diseases of the Nervous System > a. Dominant/nondominant side

content.full_text: Codes from category G81, Hemiplegia and hemiparesis, and subcategories G83.1, Monoplegia of lower limb, G83.2, Monoplegia of upper limb, and G83.3, Monoplegia, unspecified, identify whether the dominant or nondominant side is affected. Should the affected side be documented, but not specified as dominant or nondominant, and the classification system does not indicate a default, code selection is as follows: • For ambidextrous patients, the default should be dominant. • If the left side is affected, the default is non-dominant. • If the right side is affected, the default is dominant. (Evidence: pg no: 45, L10-L15)
content.summary: Default rules for assigning dominant/nondominant side when documentation specifies affected side but not dominance status. (Evidence: pg no: 45, L10-L15)
key_concepts: Dominant/nondominant side identification (Evidence: pg no: 45, L10-L11)
Default assignment rules (Evidence: pg no: 45, L12)
Ambidextrous patient handling (Evidence: pg no: 45, L13)
Left/right side defaults (Evidence: pg no: 45, L14-L15)

detailed_rules.rule_text: For ambidextrous patients, the default should be dominant (Evidence: pg no: 45, L13)
detailed_rules.explanation: When a patient is ambidextrous and dominance is not specified, always default to dominant side coding (Evidence: pg no: 45, L13)

detailed_rules.rule_text: If the left side is affected, the default is non-dominant (Evidence: pg no: 45, L14)
detailed_rules.explanation: When left side is documented as affected but dominance not specified, assign non-dominant codes (Evidence: pg no: 45, L14)

detailed_rules.rule_text: If the right side is affected, the default is dominant (Evidence: pg no: 45, L15)
detailed_rules.explanation: When right side is documented as affected but dominance not specified, assign dominant codes (Evidence: pg no: 45, L15)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify affected side from documentation
Step 2: Check if dominance is specifically documented
Step 3: If dominance not specified, apply default rules
Step 4: For ambidextrous patients, use dominant
Step 5: For left side affected, use non-dominant
Step 6: For right side affected, use dominant

code_ranges.description: Hemiplegia and hemiparesis with dominant/nondominant specifications (Evidence: pg no: 45, L10-L11)
usage_rules: Apply default rules when dominance not specified (Evidence: pg no: 45, L12)

specific_codes.description: Monoplegia of lower limb (Evidence: pg no: 45, L11)
Monoplegia of upper limb (Evidence: pg no: 45, L11)

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient with right-sided hemiplegia, dominance not documented
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Patient presents with right hemiplegia following stroke
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify right side is affected
Step 3: Apply default rule for right side = dominant

correct_coding.rationale: Right side default is dominant when not specified (Evidence: pg no: 45, L15)

incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Not applying right side = dominant default

warnings: Only apply defaults when classification system doesn't indicate a default (Evidence: pg no: 45, L12)
best_practices: Always check documentation for specific dominance information first
Apply default rules consistently based on affected side
common_mistakes: Not applying default rules when dominance unspecified
Incorrect default assignment for left/right sides
tips: Remember: Right = dominant, Left = non-dominant as defaults
Ambidextrous patients always default to dominant
implementation_notes: Rules apply when classification system has no default
Documentation of affected side is prerequisite
